snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you everyone for worrying about demonetization. Thanks to our patrons (high five!) and our sponsors (Go to http://Brilliant.org/SciShow to try out Brilliant’s Daily Challenges. The first 200 subscribers get 20% off an annual Premium subscription.) we don't ever have to worry about whether any individual video is going to get demonetized. Obviously, even if we did, we would still cover topics like this, but it is nice to not have it even enter our minds. Honestly, the subject of whether this video would be monetized literally never came up in the office and that's entirely because of Patreon, so thank you for your support.

And now I'm gonna go wash my hands now because I just high fived a bunch of people.

- Hank

snippet.textDisplay:
COVID-19 Update!

COVID-19 (2019-nCoV): Hypochlorous Acid (150ppm) achieved > 5 log reduction in FCV titres in less than a minute!

What is Hypochlorous Acid?

Hypochlorous Acid is used in many industries including Hospitality, Food service, Grocery/ Retail, Post harvest vegetable production, Hydroponics, and Medical services.

ECA Water (Electrochemically Activated Water) water is made by passing low-voltage electricity through saltwater (Sodium Chloride) in the ECA-1 and splitting the Sodium ions (Catholyte) from the Chlorine ions (Anolyte – Hypochlorous acid).

Is it safe? 

When any mammal’s body comes under attack from invading bacteria and viruses, the body’s immune system immediately responds by sending white blood cells called Neutrophil to the invasion site.

Once activated, these cells produce substantial quantities of Hypochlorous acid (HOCI) a chemical that is acknowledged to be among the most potent natural disinfectants, highly effective in eliminating all invading microbes and pathogens, yet it remains non-toxic to humans and other mammals.

Hypochlorous acid is proven to be safe, environmentally friendly, and fast acting against a broad range of resistant pathogens, including MRSA, M.tuberculosis, Legionella, E.coli, HIV, Poliovirus, Helicobacter Pylori ...

https://www.slideshare.net/Intersperse/eca1-commercial-hocl-manufacturing-cell
snippet.textOriginal:
COVID-19 Update! 

COVID-19 (2019-nCoV): Hypochlorous Acid (150ppm) achieved > 5 log reduction in FCV titres in less than a minute!

What is Hypochlorous Acid?

Hypochlorous Acid is used in many industries including Hospitality, Food service, Grocery/ Retail, Post harvest vegetable production, Hydroponics, and Medical services.

ECA Water (Electrochemically Activated Water) water is made by passing low-voltage electricity through saltwater (Sodium Chloride) in the ECA-1 and splitting the Sodium ions (Catholyte) from the Chlorine ions (Anolyte – Hypochlorous acid).

Is it safe? 

When any mammal’s body comes under attack from invading bacteria and viruses, the body’s immune system immediately responds by sending white blood cells called Neutrophil to the invasion site. 

Once activated, these cells produce substantial quantities of Hypochlorous acid (HOCI) a chemical that is acknowledged to be among the most potent natural disinfectants, highly effective in eliminating all invading microbes and pathogens, yet it remains non-toxic to humans and other mammals.

Hypochlorous acid is proven to be safe, environmentally friendly, and fast acting against a broad range of resistant pathogens, including MRSA, M.tuberculosis, Legionella, E.coli, HIV, Poliovirus, Helicobacter Pylori ... 

https://www.slideshare.net/Intersperse/eca1-commercial-hocl-manufacturing-cell

In this video there are so much miss iinformation that I can't understand.... But either way DO NOT PANIC is good start.... Italy is complete shut down all as of writing this... So lets crunch numbers: 970 million people in China was quarantine just because your normal flu right? NO its novel which means its complete new strain of virus that humanity has never seen... Nor have immunity against it also there are 2 DIFFERENT STRAIN as of this writing so called S and L type S is the orginal that was less severe and L type mutated at some point(no info when this happened) that is the worse of the 2.... Also the asymptomatic time can be ENYTHING 5 days up to even as long as 27 days(few cases that have been confirmed about this)


The good thing though is that 80% atm get mild symptoms 15% severe and 5% critical

snippet.textDisplay:
I have had pneumonia for over a week. I just took my last antibiotic for it this morning. Before I got an x-ray I 100% thought I had coronavirus and was trying not to physically go to the doctor.

I put gloves on and a mask so I didn't transfer it when I went in for my x Ray. I didn't want to accidentally kill someone.

Pneumonia kills people too, so the effort wasn't wasted. I hope I don't get coronavirus cuz I'm kinda just... Done with not being able to breathe.

I don't think that me or my nuclear family will die from it, but I'm worried for my grandparents. They're really frail. I think that going grocery shopping for them would be wise. They'll go stir crazy being locked up in their house for a month or more, but it's better than dead.
snippet.textOriginal:

Pneumonia kills people too, so the effort wasn't wasted. I hope I don't get coronavirus cuz I'm kinda just... Done with not being able to breathe. 

I don't think that me or my nuclear family will die from it, but I'm worried for my grandparents. They're really frail. I think that going grocery shopping for them would be wise. They'll go stir crazy being locked up in their house for a month or more, but it's better than dead.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you :) That's much clearer as to why the resistance to naming it a "pandemic" now,

so basically if it gets called a "pandemic"actions like the recent quarantine in Italy no longer happen & the virus is just allowed to run it's course & so at this point it's in everyone's best interests to avoid that term so as to encourage continued attempts at containment.



We know now of course that we can't actually contain it, but we can temporarily put in some contaminants so as to reduce hospital burdens & yes that, you would think, would be the same as just calling it a pandemic & using mitigation, but I can see how some idiot world leaders wouldn't grasp that, so probably best to idiot proof the name so as to get the preferred action from governments in spreading over time the virus load on hospitals & medical services globally.


Thanks again for the clear explanation :) Not a stock market thing, is a management idiotproofing thing

snippet.textDisplay: Here in upstate NY we've had a mixed bag of cancellations. One of our Philharmonics just cancelled/postponed the rest of its season for COVID-19 but the anime convention from the same city is so far still booked for the weekend after next. Somehow I feel like I'm more afraid of community spread at an anime convention then sitting in a concert hall. It also will bring in a lot wider radius of people than the orchestra 😂

snippet.textDisplay:
New Minor Disease Spreading
"In a normal checkup, a doctor in China spotted a new disease in a patient and has named it COVID-19, it seems mostly harmless, but must be investigated further."
snippet.textOriginal:
New Minor Disease Spreading
"In a normal checkup, a doctor in China spotted a new disease in a patient and has named it COVID-19, it seems mostly harmless, but must be investigated further."

snippet.textDisplay: Please, COVID-19 is a pandemic disease, seriously. In China, with extraordinary intensive medical interference and forceful strict quarantine, the R0 of spreading is 2-3. Seems alright? The SARS in 2003 was 0.85-3! H1N1 influenza in 1918 is 2-3. Who knows what will happen if there were no treatment? What's more, COVID 19 is more tricky than SARS was. It begins to be infectious even in the asymptomatic stage while SARS did not. Sadly, the asymptotic period is 3-7 days. How many people can be infected in 3 days? So far the patient median age is 48, fatality for an age lower than 35 is one decimal, over 45 is 1 percent, 60 is 3-5. If you are an old man with a smoking history or some complications, it boosts to 9 percent! No one wants to lose their loved ones. Even you are young and can survive from this disease, please, consider your medical bill and aged parents. Protect yourself to make them safe.
snippet.textOriginal: Please, COVID-19 is a pandemic disease, seriously. In China, with extraordinary intensive medical interference and forceful strict quarantine, the R0 of spreading is 2-3. Seems alright? The SARS in 2003 was 0.85-3! H1N1 influenza in 1918 is 2-3. Who knows what will happen if there were no treatment? What's more, COVID 19 is more tricky than SARS was. It begins to be infectious even in the asymptomatic stage while SARS did not. Sadly, the asymptotic period is 3-7 days. How many people can be infected in 3 days? So far the patient median age is 48, fatality for an age lower than 35 is one decimal, over 45 is 1 percent, 60 is 3-5. If you are an old man with a smoking history or some complications, it boosts to 9 percent! No one wants to lose their loved ones. Even you are young and can survive from this disease, please, consider your medical bill and aged parents. Protect yourself to make them safe.

snippet.textDisplay: ok so the Coronavirus is a huge deal, no doubt... since it’s worldwide now and pretty much all of Italy is under quarantine now, but in the US, tens of thousands of people die from influenza every year, and as of today (March 9,2020) coronavirus only has 20 deaths in the US. Influenza is a bigger threat in the states than coronavirus. Also, the media is hyping up the coronavirus, it is actually not a huge threat. Yes there will be a lot of cases, however, most people who are initially healthy will survive. We just have to worry about others with weak immune systems, and people with heart and lung problems.

snippet.textDisplay: Between December and January, almost everyone I worked with at SeaTac (Seattle-Tacoma International Airport) was sick. None of us knew what it was cause it didn't feel like your typical cold or flu. Just a really annoying cough, with some of us calling out sick cause they got a fever. After a while though, we were all better, and forgot about it until this pandemic started. Thinking about it now, having been in contact with thousands of people from China everyday, it might have been Covid19, and we all probably spread it to the many communities around WA that we lived in.

snippet.textDisplay:
Everyone is so worried about a virus that has killed only about 3,000 worldwide in 2.3 months.

No one gives a single pause to the flu which has killed over 10,000 in the U.S. alone in the same timeframe.

COVID-19 has hospitalized 10s of thousands worldwide.
Meanwhile the flu has hopitalized almost 1 million in just the U.S. in the same timeframe.

COVID-19 has hit 100,000 infections worldwide.
The flu you may ask? Over 18,000,000 in the U.S. alone in the same timeframe.

I see we have our hysteria priorities in the right place.

snippet.textDisplay:
The WHO is refraining from using the term "pandemic" because they caught a lot of flack for adding unnecessary hysteria to the Swine Flu pandemic is 2009...hence retiring pandemic as an official term.
If you look at the 2009 H1N1 pandemic, it should have taught us a lot for this current outbreak, the timeline of outbreak, and their classification of "pandemic" would be now in March 2020. Also, the rate of infection is similar.

I do think we will eventually have to classify Covid-19 as a pandemic, but we're also facing a greater infodemic with the over saturation of media being almost 4 times greater than in 2009. The H1N1 pandemic in 2009 officially lasted a year and that's probably what will happen here.
snippet.textOriginal:
The WHO is refraining from using the term "pandemic" because they caught a lot of flack for adding unnecessary hysteria to the Swine Flu pandemic is 2009...hence retiring pandemic as an official term. 
If you look at the 2009 H1N1 pandemic, it should have taught us a lot for this current outbreak, the timeline of outbreak, and their classification of "pandemic" would be now in March 2020. Also, the rate of infection is similar.  

I do think we will eventually have to classify Covid-19 as a pandemic, but we're also facing a greater infodemic with the over saturation of media being almost 4 times greater than in 2009. The  H1N1 pandemic in 2009 officially lasted a year and that's probably what will happen here.
